questions.question_text: Which of the following connector types can be used to connect a laptop to a docking station or port replicator? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: I did some small searches and i think on average docking ports use USB-C and since thunderbolt is also like a USB-C (interchangeable?) therefore... Honestly this question is evil.

comments.content: I got this question on the exam today lol
Just another CompTIA lame question...

discussion.content: Docking ports and docking stations are proprietary . That is, the port works only with docking stations designed by the laptop’s manufacturer and vice versa.

Answer is B & E
Really secure boot - https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-hardware/design/device-experiences/oem-secure-boot

Selected Answer: BD
I might be wrong here, but I think it is BD (disable secure boot) because if you check BIOS for updates before you install, what would that do? Wouldn't you have to update it AFTER installation? And the question is asking what should you do before. You can't update anything if nothing was added.
did anyone get this question on the test and got b and e correct?

comments.content: A typo: "secure boot whould be the problem"

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BE
BIOS updates can contain support for newer CPUs that did not exists during the manufacturing of the motherboard. (you know... the place where the BIOS is located).

The fact that the PC does not boot means that it is NOT at the stage to Post into the OS 
During the Post process the BIOS configuration (your settings) are being loaded.
this includes the secure boot setting.
if the system did boot and the secure boot should be the problem you could receive an error. like: "boot device not found"

i hope this clears things up :)

Selected Answer: BE
The fact it doesn't even boot means you can't access BIOS, which eliminates most of the choices and leaves you with B, C or E. It can't be C because the computer can still boot without case cooling.
I've built a couple of PCs before and you definitely want to check for BIOS versions in case you need to flash BIOS for your CPU > E is correct.
Obviously if your CPU doesn't have enough power the PC won't turn on > B is correct.

Selected Answer: BE
Updating the bios makes the most sense before disabling the secure boot
system no longer boots... checking for a bios update would do nothing for this.

comments.content: The question asks what technician didn't do before..
You are absolutely wrong. BIOS updates are released with updated support for newer CPUs. Secure Boot here is useless.
Says WHO? Try updating the BIOS without disabling secure boot and see what happens!
Motherboards nowadays support BIOS flashing with a physical button on the back panel. You don't have to touch anything in the BIOS.
i upgraded my ryzen 3000 to a 5000 recently and i didn't disable anything. I instead update my bios ;). Everything went smooth
Secure boot here makes no sense

Drivers facilitate hardware communication with the Operating System and Secure Boot is a security feature protecting UEFI. You need to upgrade the BIOS to support the new CPU so that it's recognized by the motherboard. AFTER that's done and you boot into the OS, THEN you would update any drivers. You don't install and update drivers before installing the hardware.

The reason you would disable secure boot is to allow unsigned driver updates for the processor. Secure boot stops updates that aren't signed for. If it is not working then the chances are the driver update has not happened. It may not be signed.

discussion.content: Would not it be "Check for Bios Updates" instead of "Disable Secure boot" ?

questions.question_text:
A user purchased a processor to upgrade a computer. After the installation, the computer no longer boots, but everything appears to be installed correctly.
Which of the following should the user have done prior to installing the new processor? (Choose two.)

choices.B: Verify the power requirements of the new CPU

discussion.content: A built-in battery case is a phone case that has an integrated battery pack. It is designed to provide additional power to your phone when its battery is running low. These cases are available for a variety of phone models, including the iPhone 13 1. They can provide up to 150% more battery power than the phone’s natural battery life. A battery case is a convenient way to keep your phone charged when you’re on the go and don’t have access to an outlet.
wait I'm confused, it not the wireless charger

comments.content: No, because you have to plug in the wireless charging pad into an outlet.
They just confused us with terminology lol

discussion.content: no power bank as an option?

questions.question_text:
Ann, a user, needs to attend several day-long conferences and wants to ensure her mobile device will have enough power for these events. She is concerned about wall outlet availability at the conferences and needs to continuously use her device for important updates.
Which of the following should a technician recommend to BEST accommodate Ann's needs?

A technician receives a laptop from an end user who reports that some aspects of the image are left behind when applications are closed and persist until reboot.
The technician also notices black dots throughout the screen. The technician recalibrates the display settings and updates the drivers for the display adapter, but the issue persists.
Which of the following is the laptop MOST likely experiencing? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: Professor messer also states that images that persist after the application is closed is an Artifact in a video, and burn in is described as an image that wont go away.. since in this scenario the image went away after a reboot we can eliminate burn in from the answer choices. disregard my last explanation. I had not look far enough into this.

Selected Answer: AE
Burn in wouldn't go away on reboot.

Selected Answer: AE
As stated by Ty_ty : " images that persist after the application is closed is an Artifact in a video, and burn in is described as an image that wont go away" so, A&E (not the TV channel) are the answers.
Image persistence is temporary. Burn-in is permanent.
Burn-in does not go away
professor messer describes a burn in as the same issue described here. turn off the monitor and turn it back on and the problem went away... aka problem persists until reboot.

Believe dead pixels and burn-in are correct. For LCDs "burn-in develops in some cases because pixels permanently lose their ability to return to their relaxed state after a continued static use profile. In most typical usage profiles, this image persistence in LCD is only transient." For LCDs, this is interpreted as "image persistence" which is emphasized in the question as "persist until reboot." Don't think of this as traditional burn-in.

comments.content: CompTia should still be using "image persistence" instead of "burn-in."
I think it's A and E. The CompTIA manual refers to image persistence that disappears after shutting down the pc as artifacts.

discussion.content: "some aspects of the image are left behind when applications are closed and persist until reboot" How can this mean "burnt in"?

choices.A: RAID 1 configuration that will utilize new SSD
choices.C: RAID 6 configuration that will allow the loss of two hard drives without failure
choices.B: RAID 5 configuration that will allow the loss of a hard drive without failure

questions.question_text:
A customer's workstation will not boot. A technician runs diagnostics on the system and discovers it is set up in a RAID 0 configuration, and a single SATA hard drive has failed. The system was set up for performance. Once repaired, the customer requests redundancy be built into the system and an increase in performance.
Which of the following describes how the technician should set up the new RAID configuration?

discussion.content: A? anyone else?

comments.content: yea A seemed correct to me. I guess RAID 10 is just like an extra extra upgrade?
But RAID 1 with SSDs is much better than RAID 10 with HDDs
Exactly, it is RAID 1 using SSDs.
The question says nothing about wanting to maintain striping. But it does say that he wants increased performance.

"Once repaired, the customer requests redundancy be built into the system and an increase in performance."

The customer is asking for redundancy to be added to the current set up, which already has stripping so stripping needs to be maintained.
RAID 10 because he still wants to maintain striping while having redundancy. Having RAID 1 would just be mirroring, which would reduce speed comparatively to RAID 0.

discussion.content:
Raid 1 has slow write speeds when compared with Raid 5. So it's not A.
RAID 10 is more efficient in that it's able to keep the drives active (at a maximum) more so than RAID 5. However, for maximum performance (actual writing speed), RAID 5 is better because less time is used storing information that is redundant.
The user wants improved redundancy and performance, no mention of cost, so why use outdated HDD? In my opinion, RAID 5 with SSD is the best bet.

Tricky Question:
IMO - 
A.) RAID 1 (New SSD) - No indication what type of drive is currently used and RAID 1 isn't best for performance.

C.) RAID 6 - Not covered in course material

D. RAID 10 (New HDD) - No indication what type of drive is being used in question and how many drives already installed.

B. RAID 5 Only answer by definition that resolves customer request without scenario assumptions. Better performance then RAID 0 with redundancy.
Raid 0 -best performance. Raid 1 - primarly for redundancy = Raid 1+0 best redundancy and speed (performance) from steadfast.net

only way to justify D answer is that only 1 hd has failed, and the guy had to replace only one hd. Putting a ssd mirrored with an hdd doesn't make much sense, so is best going with a raid 10 hd...i suppose. (Still should be better buy 2 ssd instead of 3 new hdd, but hey, comptia love raid hdd)

comments.content: He still has the other HDD which is still working fine. Not sure you can configure RAID 1 with a mix of HDD and SSD if you go with A..

discussion.content: I think RAID 1 with SSD would be the BEST answer. IDK why its RAID 10 but i guess COMPTIA just wanna make you confused.
Could the keywords be "Once repaired"? The new HDD is installed already.

found on other forums
"SSD doesn't have a "speed". It's a technology category. So we'd have to make some huge assumptions.

4x 15K on RAID 10 is in the ballpark of 400 Read IOPS / 200 Write IOPS

A typical desktop class SSD pair in RAID 1 will be 100,000 Read IOPS / 50,000 Write IOPS
it does looks like its A

https://blog.storagecraft.com/raid-performance/

Based off the following article I want to say A is the answer. However, maybe the key detail here is "once repaired". So he already purchased a replacement HDD. Even so... the article states that RAID 10 cuts write performance in half compared to RAID 0 so... this can't possibly be the answer unless CompTIA really is that technologically and logically illiterate. 

I'm going with A.
you know what, I think you guys are right, RAID 1 w SSD. he wants to increase the performance.
the question is asking... Which of the following describes how the technician should set up the new RAID Config.... he wants speed and redundancy... Comptia answer would be RAID 10. final answer
